visuals.title: From Exponential FS to Trigonometric FS
visuals.description: The exponential FS uses complex exponentials e^{jkω₀t}. Combining +k and −k terms using Euler's formula gives the trigonometric form with real cosines and sines.

x:
Exponential FS
x(t) = Σ X_k e^{jkω₀t}

Trigonometric FS
a₀/2 + Σ(a_k cos + b_k sin)

visuals.title: Coefficient Relationships: X_k ↔ a_k, b_k
visuals.description: a_k = 2Re{X_k}, b_k = −2Im{X_k}, X_k = (a_k − jb_k)/2. These convert between the two FS forms.

visuals.title: Orthogonal Cosines: cos(ω₀t) and cos(2ω₀t)
visuals.description: The product cos(ω₀t)·cos(2ω₀t) oscillates symmetrically and integrates to zero over one period. This is orthogonality.

visuals.title: Orthogonality Inner Product Table
visuals.description: ⟨cos(mω₀t), cos(nω₀t)⟩ = 0 when m ≠ n, and = T₀/2 when m = n. Same for sines. Cross terms (cos-sin) always zero.

x:
⟨cos m, sin n⟩
any m, n

visuals.title: Cosine and Sine Are Always Orthogonal
visuals.description: cos(kω₀t) and sin(kω₀t) are orthogonal for any k: their product integrates to zero over one period.

visuals.title: Symmetry in the TFS: Even → Cosines Only, Odd → Sines Only
visuals.description: Even signals x(t) = x(−t) have b_k = 0 (only cosines). Odd signals x(t) = −x(−t) have a_k = 0 (only sines).

text:
b_k = 0
Cosines ONLY
a₀/2 + Σa_k cos(kω₀t)

visuals.title: TFS of a Standard Square Wave: Only Odd Sine Harmonics
visuals.description: An odd square wave has only sine terms with odd k: x(t) = (4/π)Σ sin(kω₀t)/k for k = 1, 3, 5, ...

visuals.title: Interactive: Build a Signal with Cosines and Sines
visuals.description: Adjust individual a_k and b_k coefficients. Watch the signal update in real time as you add cosine and sine harmonics.

visuals.title: Interactive: Test Orthogonality by Choosing m and n
visuals.description: Choose m and n, see the product cos(mω₀t)·cos(nω₀t), and verify the integral is zero when m ≠ n.

visuals.title: Same Signal, Two Representations
visuals.description: The same periodic signal represented by exponential FS (complex coefficients) and trigonometric FS (real cosines/sines). Both reconstruct identically.

traces.name: x(t) — both FS forms give this

annotations.text: EFS and TFS are equivalent representations
